quote.title: Quote Quiz
quote.description: Identify the philosophical tradition from famous quotes

concept.title: Concept Quiz
concept.description: Identify the philosophical tradition from key concepts

questions.quote: Focus only on what is within your control‚Äîyour thoughts, actions, and responses. Accept everything else with tranquil indifference.
questions.concept: The practice of distinguishing between what is within our control (our thoughts, actions, responses) and what is not (external events), leading to inner peace through acceptance of fate.

questions.quote: You are condemned to be free, and with that freedom comes the terrifying responsibility to create your own meaning and essence.
questions.concept: The belief that humans are 'thrown' into existence without choosing it, yet must take full responsibility for creating their own meaning and essence through authentic choices.

questions.quote: The right action is the one that produces the greatest happiness for the greatest number of people, regardless of personal preferences.
questions.concept: The principle that moral actions should be judged solely by their consequences in maximizing overall happiness or well-being for the greatest number of people.

questions.quote: The superior person cultivates virtue through ritual propriety, filial piety, and harmonious relationships within the natural social order.
questions.concept: The ideal of the exemplary person (junzi) who achieves moral cultivation through proper relationships, respect for tradition, ritual propriety, and social harmony.

questions.quote: All suffering arises from attachment and craving; liberation comes through mindful detachment and the cessation of desire.
questions.concept: The Four Noble Truths: suffering exists, it arises from attachment and craving, it can be ended, and the Eightfold Path leads to liberation (nirvana).

questions.quote: The material world is merely a shadow of eternal, perfect Forms‚Äîtrue knowledge comes from understanding these unchanging ideals.
questions.concept: The Theory of Forms - reality consists of perfect, eternal, unchanging Forms, while the material world is merely an imperfect reflection of these ideals.

questions.quote: Virtue lies in the golden mean between extremes; excellence is achieved through habit and the cultivation of good character.
questions.concept: The doctrine of the mean - virtue is found in the balanced middle ground between extremes of excess and deficiency, developed through repeated practice.

questions.quote: All individuals possess natural rights to life, liberty, and property that no government may justly violate without consent.
questions.concept: Natural rights theory - humans have inherent rights to life, liberty, and property that precede government, and legitimate political authority requires consent of the governed.

questions.quote: History is the story of class struggle; workers must unite to overthrow the capitalist system that alienates them from their labor.
questions.concept: Historical materialism and class struggle - economic relations drive historical change, and capitalism creates alienation that can only be resolved through revolution.

questions.quote: There are no objective truths, universal morals, or inherent meanings‚Äîonly the values we courageously create for ourselves.
questions.concept: The rejection of objective values - traditional moral and religious foundations are groundless, requiring individuals to create their own values and meaning.

questions.quote: What does not kill you makes you stronger‚Äîembrace the eternal recurrence and become who you truly are.
questions.concept: Amor fati (love of fate) - embracing what occurs rather than fighting against it, finding peace through alignment with the natural order and resilience through adversity.

questions.quote: We are thrown into existence without our choosing, yet we must take full responsibility for every choice we make.
questions.concept: Thrownness (Geworfenheit) - we find ourselves existing in a world we didn't choose, yet must take full responsibility for how we respond to this condition.

questions.quote: It is better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied.
questions.concept: Qualitative hedonism - higher pleasures of the mind are more valuable than lower physical pleasures, even if they involve more complexity and potential dissatisfaction.

questions.quote: The gentleman understands what is right; the petty man understands what is profitable.
questions.concept: Moral versus material priorities - the cultivated person prioritizes righteousness and virtue over personal gain and profit in all decisions.

questions.quote: Pain is inevitable, but suffering is optional‚Äîmindfulness reveals the impermanent nature of all phenomena.
questions.concept: The distinction between pain and suffering - physical pain is unavoidable, but psychological suffering comes from our attachment to permanence in an impermanent world.

questions.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living‚Äîtrue wisdom begins with knowing that you know nothing.
questions.concept: Socratic wisdom and self-knowledge - intellectual humility and constant questioning are essential for philosophical understanding and a meaningful life.

questions.quote: We are what we repeatedly do; excellence is not an act, but a habit formed through practical wisdom.
questions.concept: Virtue as habit (hexis) - moral excellence is developed through repeated practice guided by practical wisdom (phronesis), not through single acts.

questions.quote: The only way to deal with an unfree world is to become so absolutely free that your very existence is an act of rebellion.
questions.concept: Individual autonomy and resistance to tyranny - personal freedom requires active resistance to social and political forces that constrain human liberty.

questions.quote: The philosophers have only interpreted the world; the point is to change it through revolutionary praxis.
questions.concept: Praxis over theory - philosophy should not merely analyze reality but actively work to transform unjust social and economic conditions through revolutionary action.

questions.quote: God is dead, and we have killed him‚Äînow we must become gods ourselves and create new values.
questions.concept: The death of God and transvaluation - traditional religious/moral authorities have lost their power, requiring humans to create new values and meaning.

questions.quote: The discipline of desire teaches us to want what happens, not what we wish would happen.
questions.concept: The discipline of desire - finding contentment by wanting what happens rather than demanding that reality conform to our wishes.

questions.quote: Hell is other people‚Äîwe are defined by the gaze of others, yet we must authentically choose ourselves.
questions.concept: Bad faith and the look of the other - we often define ourselves through others' perceptions, but authentic existence requires choosing our own identity.

questions.quote: Actions are right in proportion as they tend to promote happiness; wrong as they tend to produce the reverse.
questions.concept: The principle of utility restated - moral rightness is determined purely by consequences that maximize happiness and minimize suffering for all affected.

questions.quote: The ruler who governs by virtue is like the North Star‚Äîfixed in place while all other stars orbit around it.
questions.concept: Rule by moral example - virtuous leadership naturally attracts followers and creates order without coercion, like celestial harmony in the natural world.

questions.quote: Form is emptiness, emptiness is form‚Äîall phenomena arise through dependent origination and have no inherent existence.
questions.concept: Emptiness (≈õ≈´nyatƒÅ) and dependent origination - all phenomena lack independent existence and arise only through interconnected relationships with other phenomena.

questions.quote: The soul is like a charioteer trying to control two horses‚Äîone noble, one base‚Äîas it ascends toward the realm of Forms.
questions.concept: The tripartite soul - reason must control both spirit and appetite to achieve wisdom and approach the eternal realm of perfect Forms.

questions.quote: The whole is greater than the sum of its parts‚Äîunderstanding requires grasping the final cause or purpose.
questions.concept: Teleological thinking and holism - true understanding comes from recognizing the purpose or end goal that gives meaning to individual components.

questions.quote: Government derives its just powers from the consent of the governed, and people have the right to revolution when it fails them.
questions.concept: Social contract theory - legitimate government exists only through popular consent, and people retain the right to overthrow tyrannical rule.

questions.quote: The bourgeoisie cannot exist without constantly revolutionizing the instruments of production and the relations of society.
questions.concept: Capitalism's revolutionary nature - the capitalist system inherently disrupts traditional social relations through constant technological and economic innovation.

questions.quote: The abyss gazes also into you‚Äîwhen you stare into meaninglessness, you must will your own meaning into existence.
questions.concept: The abyss and will to power - confronting meaninglessness changes us, but we can overcome nihilism by actively creating our own values and purpose.
